revision.comment: /* Ritual slaughter */ Passive voice to active voice, changed sentence structure and fixed spelling mistake.
revision.text:
{{Islam|culture|width=20.0em}}
In [[Islam]], [[God in Islam|God]] is in a relationship with '''animals''': according to the [[Quran|Qur'an]], they praise him, even if this praise is not expressed in [[human language]].<ref name="ReferenceA">See {{cite quran|17|44|style=ref}}</ref><ref name="EoR&N">"Islam, Animals, and Vegetarianism" in the ''Encyclopedia of Religion and Nature'' (Bron Taylor (chief ed.), Continuum International Publishing Group Ltd., 2008).</ref> [[Animal-baiting|Baiting animals]] for [[entertainment]] or [[gambling]] is prohibited.<ref name="Al-Adab al-Mufrad, 1: 1232">[[Al-Adab al-Mufrad]], Book 1, [[Hadith]] 1232</ref><ref name="ArmstrongBotzler">{{cite book |title=The Animal Ethics Reader |author1=Susan J. Armstrong |author2=Richard G. Botzler |pages=235–237 |publisher=Routledge (UK) Press |isbn=0415275881 }}</ref>
The [[Quran]] explicitly allows the eating of the meat of certain ''[[halal]]'' ({{lang-ar|حَـلَال}}, lawful) animals.<ref name="EoR&N"/><ref>See {{cite quran|5|1|style=ref}}</ref> Although some [[Sufism|Sufi]]s have practised [[vegetarianism]], there has been no serious discourse on the possibility of vegetarian interpretations.<ref name="EoR&N" /> Certain animals can be eaten under the condition that they are slaughtered in a specified way.<ref name="die">[[Javed Ahmad Ghamidi]] (2001): [http://www.renaissance.com.pk/febislaw2y2.html The Dietary Laws] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070502045147/http://www.renaissance.com.pk/febislaw2y2.html |date=May 2, 2007 }}</ref> "Stunning cannot be used to kill an animal, according to the Halal Food Authority (HFA), a non-profit organisation that monitors adherence to halal principles. But it can be used if the animal survives and is then killed by halal methods, the HFA adds," reports the [[BBC]].<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-27324224</ref> Prohibitions include [[Domestic pig|swine]], [[carrion]],<ref name=autogenerated2>[[John Esposito]] (2002b), p.111</ref> and animals involved in ''[[dhabihah]]'' ({{lang-ar|ذَبِـيـحَـة}}, [[ritual slaughter]]) in the name of someone other than God.<ref name="die" /> The Quran also states "eat of that over which the name of [[Allah]], hath been mentioned."<ref>See {{cite quran|6|118|style=ref}}</ref> {{TOC limit|2}}
== Animals in pre-Islamic Arabia == In [[pre-Islamic Arabia]], [[Arab]] [[Bedouin]], like other people, attributed the qualities and the faults of humans to animals. Generosity, for example, was attributed to the [[Cock (bird)|cock]]; [[perfidy]] to the [[lizard]]; stupidity to the [[bustard]]; and boldness to the [[lion]].<ref name="Hayawan"/>
Based on the facts that the names of certain tribes bear the names of animals, survivals of animal cults, prohibitions of certain foods and other indications, W.  R. Smith argued for the practice of [[Totem#Totemism|totemism]] by certain [[tribes of Arabia]]. Others have argued that this evidence may only imply practice of a form of [[Personal identity|animalism]]. In support of this, for example, it was believed that upon one's death, the soul departs from the body in the form of a bird (usually a sort of [[owl]]); the soul-as-bird then flies about the tomb for some time, occasionally crying out (for vengeance).<ref>{{cite web |last1=Subhani |first1=Ayatullah Jafar |title=THE MESSAGE |url=https://www.al-islam.org/the-message-ayatullah-jafar-subhani/chapter-2-arabia-islam |publisher=Islamic Seminary Publications}}</ref>
== Human duties in utilizing animals == {{Tone|section|date=September 2018}} {{copy edit|section|date=September 2018}}
According to Islam, human beings are allowed to use animals, but only if their rights are respected. The owner of an animal must do everything they can to benefit the animal. If the owner fails to perform their duties for the animal, nobody else has the right to use them. The duties humans have for animals in Islam are based on the [[Quran]], [[Sunnah]] and [[Hadith|traditions]].<ref name="z">{{cite web |last1=Tavakkoli |first1=Saeid Nazari |title=ANIMALS WELFARE ACTS AND UTILIZATION LIMITS IN ISLAM |url=https://www.al-islam.org/animals-welfare-acts-utilization-limits-islam-saeid-nazari-tavakkoli |publisher=Islamic Research Foundation Astan-e Quds Razavi}}</ref>
=== Protection of animal lives === From the Islamic perspective, animal protection is more important than the fulfillment of certain religious obligations in special circumstances.<ref name="z"/> (... that whoever kills a soul unless for a soul or for corruption [done] in the land - it is as if he had slain mankind entirely. And whoever saves one - it is as if he had saved mankind entirely...)<ref>See {{cite quran|5|32|style=ref}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Bukhari |first1=Imam |title=Al-Adab Al-Mufrad |publisher=UK Islamic Academy (January 1, 2006) |isbn=978-1872531182 |pages=263–264 |url=https://www.amazon.com/Al-Adab-Al-Mufrad-Imam-Bukhari/dp/1872531180}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Thiqatu al-Islam, Abu ja'far Muhammad ibn Ya'qub |first1=al-Kulayni |title=Al-Kafi |publisher=Islamic Seminary Incorporated, The; 2 edition |isbn=978-0991430888 |page=16 |url=https://www.amazon.com/Al-Kafi-2-8-English-Translation/dp/0991430883/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1536392977&sr=1-1&keywords=Al-Kafi}}</ref>
=== Protection of animals' physical health === Harming, disabling, injuring, or cutting out the organs from any animal is prohibited. Islam strongly warns people against committing such an act.<ref name="z"/> Muslims may not cut the forelock, mane, or tail of a horse, because it is believed there is goodness in its forelock; its mane provides it warmth; and it swats insects away with its tail.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Al-Tabarsi |first1=Hasan Ibn Al-Fadl |title=Makarim Al-Akhlaq (Nobilities of Character) |isbn=978-9642194193 |page=174 |url=https://www.amazon.com/Makarim-Al-Akhlaq-Nobilities-Character-Al-Tabarsi/dp/9642194198/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1536395039&sr=1-1&keywords=Makarim+al-Akhlaq&dpID=31gLEUrLGPL&preST=_BO1,204,203,200_QL40_&dpSrc=srch}}</ref>
=== Protection of animals' sexual health === Muslims are not allowed to commit some acts like castration and interbreeding animals.<ref name="z"/> [[Muhammad in Islam|Muhammad]] forbade people from castrating animals.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Muh Shawkani |first1=Abu 'Abd Allah Muhammad Ibn 'Ali Ibn |title=Nayl al-awtar min ahadith Sayyid al-akhyar |publisher=Turath For Solutions, 2013 |isbn=9789957640934 |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Nayl_al_awtar_min_ahadith_sayyid_al_akhy.html?id=dxmxAQAACAAJ}}</ref>
=== Preventing cruelty and maltreatment to animals === From the Muslim perspective, Muslims are not allowed to harass and misuse animals, which even includes actions like snatching a leaf from an ant's mouth.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Thiqatu al-Islam, Abu ja'far Muhammad ibn Ya'qub |first1=al-Kulayni |title=Al-Kafi |publisher=Islamic Seminary Incorporated, The; 2 edition |isbn=978-0991430888 |page=11 |url=https://www.amazon.com/Al-Kafi-2-8-English-Translation/dp/0991430883/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1536392977&sr=1-1&keywords=Al-Kafi}}</ref> Muslims have no right to brand animals,<ref>{{cite book |last1='A. Muttaq |first1='Ala' Al-Din 'Ali Ibn Husam Al-Din Ibn |title=Kanz al-'ummal fi sunan al-aqwal wa-al-af'al |publisher=Turath For Solutions, 2013 |isbn=9789957672461 |page=634 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CHJ7AQAACAAJ}}</ref> even in the war they will not be [[hamstringing]] or crucifying animals before killing <ref>{{cite book |last1=al-Majlisi |first1=al-'Allama |title=Al-Mahasin |pages=243–244}}</ref> and burning them even though they cause harm to human.<ref>{{cite book |last1=al-Barqi |first1=Ahmad b. Muhammad b. Khalid |title=Bihar al-anwar |page=634}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=al-Nawawi |title=Riyad al-salihin min kalam Sayyid al-mursalin |publisher=Pt Alma`arif, 1977 |page=635}}</ref> They should not be harassed to obtain animal meat by doing things like swift and powerful slaughter,<ref>{{cite book |last1=al-Barqi |first1=Ahmad b. Muhammad b. Khalid |title=Bihar al-anwar |page=62/316}}</ref> avoid cutting lengthwise for fast die<ref>{{cite book |last1=Shahid al-Thani, Zayn al-Din ibn Ali ibn Ahmad|title=Masalik al-afham ila tanqih shara'i ' al-Islam |page=11/490}}</ref> or must be refused anything that causes interval between slaughtering and final death. In Islamic slaughter, one is not authorized to break the spinal cord by cutting its head or breaking its backbone, and even removing wool from animals is not allowed because it causes them vulnerability.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Tabatabai |first1=Allamah Sayyed Muhammad Husayn |title=Tafsir al Mizan تفسير الميزان |publisher=first published 1956 |isbn=9789646640238 |page=5/186 |url=https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/22055515-tafsir-al-mizan?rating=2&utm_medium=api&utm_source=book_widget}}</ref><ref name="z"/>
=== Avoiding punishment of animals === In Islam, Muslims are not allowed to use any equipment that damages the animal, (for example, beating them in a circus show, forcing them to carry heavy loads, or making them run at extreme speeds in races) even to train them.<ref>{{cite book |last1=al-Hur Al-Amuli |first1=Sheikh Muhammad ibn Hassan |title=Wasail Al-Shia Ila Tahsil Masaeel ash-sharia |publisher=Alalbayt le Ihya at-Turath Publication, Beirut |page=8/356–357 |url=https://almurtaza.co.uk/product/tafsil-wasail-al-shia-ila-tahsil-masaeel-ash-sharia16/}}</ref> Instead, it should use methods such as sensitization to specific sounds.<ref>{{cite book |last1=al-Majlisi |first1=al-'Allama |title=Al-Mahasin |page= 2//361}}</ref><ref name="z"/>
=== Providing foodstuffs === Muslims are obliged to provide food and water for any thirsty or hungry animal they see, even if the animal does not belong to them.<ref>{{cite book |last1=al-Barqi |first1=Ahmad b. Muhammad b. Khalid |title=Bihar al-anwar |page=61/217}}</ref> In providing food and water it should be noted a few points: 1)The quality of the Provisions.<ref>{{cite book |last1= Mirza Husayn Nuri |title= Mustadrak al-Wasa’il wa Mustanbit al-Masa’il |page=17/51}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=al-'Allama al-Hilli |title=Mukhtalaf al-Shi'a |page=8/346}}</ref> 2) The Provision rate: in this case, it should be noted the animal's condition (pregnancy, illness, working, etc.) and the place of the animal.<ref>{{cite web |last1=al-Saffar |first1=Abu Ja'far Muhammad b. al-Hasan |title=Basaair Al Darajaat 31/395 |url=https://www.hubeali.com/online-books/online-english-books/basaair-al-darajaat/}}</ref><ref name="z"/>
=== Providing sanitation === Animals' health must be respected in itself,<ref>{{cite book |last1=Thiqatu al-Islam, Abu ja'far Muhammad ibn Ya'qub |first1=al-Kulayni |title=Al-Kafi |publisher=Islamic Seminary Incorporated, The; 2 edition |isbn=978-0991430888 |url=https://www.amazon.com/Al-Kafi-2-8-English-Translation/dp/0991430883/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1536392977&sr=1-1&keywords=Al-Kafi}}</ref> its food and water,<ref>{{cite book |last1=al-Barqi |first1=Ahmad b. Muhammad b. Khalid |title=Bihar al-anwar |page=61/177}}</ref> its place of living.<ref name="z"/>
=== Providing medication === In the event an animal falls ill, Muslims are expected to pay for the care and medication.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Shahid al-Thani, Zayn al-Din ibn Ali ibn Ahmad|title=Masalik al-afham Ila tanqih shara'i ' al-Islam |page=5/88}}</ref><ref name="z"/>
=== Providing dwelling === From an Islamic view, the appropriate place for animal life should have three characteristics: 1) Fits the animal situation:<ref>{{cite book |last1=al-Barqi |first1=Ahmad b. Muhammad b. Khalid |title=Biaar Al-Anwar |page=61/318}}</ref> they should not be placed in a dirty and bad condition on the pretext that they do not understand. 2) Fits the physical needs of the animal: the place should be in such a way so as to keep the animal healthy and protect it from cold and heat.<ref>{{cite web |last1=al-Saduq |first1=al-Shaykh |title=Illal-Al-Sharaie |url=http://www.hubeali.com/online-books/online-English-books/illal-al-sharaie/}}</ref> 3) The dwelling of animals should not cause pollution of the environment or disease of other organisms.<ref name="z"/><ref>{{cite book |last1=al-Bahuti |first1=Mansur ibn Yunis ibn Idris |title=Kashshaf al-qina an matn al-iqna |publisher=maktabat al-nasr al-Haditha, 1999 |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Kashshaf_al_qina_an_matn_al_iqna.html?id=JLDyjgEACAAJ}}</ref>
=== Respecting animal of status === In Islam, the privacy of animals is respected as of humans. Respect to animals is not limited to their living time,<ref>{{cite book |last1=Imam Ibn Hazm |title=Al Muhalla |publisher=American Trust Publications |isbn=9780892590377 |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Al_Muhalla.html?id=BfNHQgAACAAJ}}</ref> but after death, it is also not right to disrespect their bodies for malicious purposes.<ref name="z"/>
== ''Quran'' ==
{{see also|List of characters and names mentioned in the Quran#Relate animals}} Although over two hundred verses in the Qur'an deal with animals and six ''[[surahs|sura]]'' (chapteral divisions) of the Qur'an are named after animals, animal life is not a predominant theme in the Qur'an;<ref name="AnimalLife">"Animal life" in the ''[[Encyclopaedia of the Qur'an]]''.</ref> ''hayawān''/''haywān'' ({{lang-ar|حَيوَان}}; plural ''haywānāt''), the [[Arabic language|Arabic]] word meaning "animal" appears only once in the Qur'an but in the sense of everlasting [[Personal life|life (personal)]].<ref name="Hayawan">"Hayawān" ("Haywān") in the ''[[Encyclopaedia of Islam]]'' (vol. 3, p. 308).</ref><ref name="AnimalLife"/> On the other hand, the term ''dābba'' ({{lang-ar|دَابَّة}}; plural ''dawābb''), usually translated as "beast" or "creature" to sometimes differentiate from flying birds while surprisingly including humans, [https://www.islamicity.org/ps/default.asp?UserString=dabba&ref=&ShowTranslation=on&ShowTransliteration=on&ShowArabic=on occurs a number of times] in the Qur'an, while remaining rare in medieval Arabic works on [[zoology]]. Animals in the Qur'an and early Muslim thought may usually (though not necessarily) be seen in terms of their relation to human beings, producing a tendency toward [[anthropocentrism]].<ref name="AnimalLife"/> <!--Superfluous?: Muslims believe the Qur’an to be a revelation to humans, not animals, and a book concerning humans.-->
The Qur'an teaches that God created animals from water.<ref name="AnimalLife"/> God cares for all his creatures and provides for them.<ref name="AnimalLife"/> All creation praises God, even if this praise is not expressed in human language.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="EoR&N" /> God has prescribed laws for each species (laws of nature). Since animals follow the laws God has ordained for them, they are to be regarded as "Muslim", just as a human who obeys the laws prescribed for humans ([[Islamic law]]) is a Muslim.<ref>"Islam" in the ''Encyclopedia of Science and Religion'' ([[op. cit.]])</ref> Just like humans, animals form "communities". In verse {{cite quran|6|38|style=ref|expand=no}}, the Qur'an applies the term ''[[ummah]]'', generally used to mean "a human religious community", for [[Genus|genera]] of animals. The ''[[Encyclopaedia of the Qur'an]]'' states that this verse has been "far reaching in its moral and [[Ecology|ecological]] implications."<ref>"Community and Society and Qur'an" in the ''Encyclopaedia of the Qur'an'' (vol. 1, p. 371)</ref>
( There is not an animal (that lives) on the earth, nor a being that flies on its wings, but (forms part of) communities like you. Nothing have we omitted from the Book, and they (all) shall be gathered to their Lord in the end.<ref>See {{cite quran|6|38|style=ref}}</ref> )
The Qur'an says that animals benefit humans in many ways and that they are aesthetically pleasing to look at. This is used a proof of God's benevolence towards humans.<ref name="AnimalLife"/> Animals that are slaughtered in accordance with sharia may be consumed.<ref name="AnimalLife"/> According to many verses of the Qur'an,<ref>See {{cite quran|2|173|style=ref}} and {{cite quran|6|145|style=ref}})</ref> the consumption of [[pork]] is [[Islamic views on sin|sinful]],<ref name=autogenerated2 /> unless there is no alternative other than starving to death (in times, for example, of war or famine).<ref>{{cite quran|2|173|quote=He hath only forbidden you dead meat, and blood, and the flesh of swine, and that on which any other name hath been invoked besides that of God. But if one is forced by necessity, without wilful disobedience, nor transgressing due limits, then is he guiltless. For God is Oft-forgiving, Most Merciful.}}</ref> ''[[Surat Yusuf]]'' of the Quran mentions that a reason why [[Jacob in Islam|Ya‘qub]] was reluctant to let his son [[Joseph in Islam|Yusuf]] to play in the open, even in the presence of his brothers, was that a [[Joseph in Islam#The plot against Joseph|wolf]] could eat him.<ref name="al-Tabari 1987 150"/><ref name="Cite quran|12|4|e=17|s=ns">{{cite quran|12|4|e=17|s=ns}}</ref>
The Quran contains three mentions of dogs: * Verse [[Al-Ma'ida|5]]:4 says "Lawful for you are all good things, and [the prey] that trained [hunting] dogs and falcons catch for you." * Verse [[Al-Kahf|18]]:18 describes the [[Seven Sleepers|Companions of the Cave]], a group of saintly young men presented in the Qurʼan as exemplars of religion, sleeping with "their dog stretching out its forelegs at the threshold." Further on, in verse 22, the dog is always counted as one of their numbers, no matter how they are numbered. In Muslim folklore, affectionate legends have grown around the loyal and protective qualities of this dog, whose name in legend is Qiṭmīr.<ref>{{cite book|last=Schimmel|first=Annemarie|title=Deciphering the Signs of God: A Phenomenological Approach to Islam|year=1994|publisher=SUNY Press|location=Albany|isbn=0791419819|page=48|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vrlwo4OqvWgC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA48|authorlink=Annemarie Schimmel|accessdate=February 16, 2014|quote=The seven pious youths 'and the eighth with them was their dog' (Sūra 18:22) have turned into protective spirits, whose names, and especially that of their dog Qiṭmīr, written on amulets, carry ''Baraka'' with them.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Bahjat|first=Ahmad|title=Animals in the Glorious Qurʼan: Relating Their Own Stories|year=2002|publisher=Islamic Inc.; Dar al-Tawzīʻ wa-al-Nashr al-Islāmīyah|location=Cairo|isbn=9772654075|pages=247–267|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cW1RJSeHklgC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA247|accessdate=February 16, 2014|chapter=The Dog of the People of the Cave}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Tlili|first=Sarra|title=Animals in the Qurʼan|year=2012|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York|isbn=9781107023703|page=250|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z_TmxaAXUiYC&lpg=PA250&pg=PA250|accessdate=February 16, 2014|quote=Al-Thaʻlabī cites an opinion according to which the dog of the Dwellers of the Cave[...] will dwell in heaven. Al-Thaʻlabī, ''al-Kashf wa-al-Bayān'' (Beirut: Dār Iḥyāʼ al-Turāth al-ʻArabī, 2002), 2:251.}}</ref>
[[Hunting dog]]s and the dog of the Companions of ''[[al-Kahf]]'' ({{lang-ar|الـكـهـف}}, the Cave) are described in a positive light, and the companionship of these dogs is mentioned with approval. The Qurʼan, thus, contains not even a hint of the condemnation of dogs found in certain ''[[Hadith]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Are dogs prohibited in the Quran?|url=http://www.quran-islam.org/articles/dogs_(P1159).html|accessdate=February 16, 2014}}</ref> There is a whole chapter in the Quran naming "The Ants". In Sunni Islam killing of Ants is prohibited.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.islamreligion.com/articles/11286/chapter-27-an-naml-ants/&ved=2ahUKEwjguvucs8TcAhUNOSsKHeIJCfAQFjASegQICBAB&usg=AOvVaw3Q9WBClbFm9c3hGxgR7-wZ|title="Chapter 27, An-Naml (The Ants)"|accessdate=July 29, 2018}}</ref><ref>Sahih Muslim, Volume 26 {http://www.theonlyquran.com/hadith/Sahih-Muslim/?volume=26&chapter=36}</ref> The Quran<ref name="Cite quran|15|80|e=84|s=ns"/><ref name="Cite quran|7|73|e=79|s=ns">{{cite quran|7|73|e=79|s=ns}}</ref><ref name="Cite quran|11|61|e=69|s=ns">{{cite quran|11|61|e=69|s=ns}}</ref><ref name="Cite quran|26|141|e=158|s=ns">{{cite quran|26|141|e=158|s=ns}}</ref><ref name="Cite quran|54|23|e=31|s=ns">{{cite quran|54|23|e=31|s=ns}}</ref><ref name="Cite quran|89|6|e=13|s=ns">{{cite quran|89|6|e=13|s=ns}}</ref><ref name="Cite quran|91|11|e=15|s=ns">{{cite quran|91|11|e=15|s=ns}}</ref> talks about a miraculous ''[[She-Camel of God]]'' ({{lang-ar|نَـاقَـة}}, 'she-camel') that came from stone, in the context of the Prophet [[Salih]], [[Thamud]]i people and [[Mada'in Saleh|Al-Hijr]].<ref name="Unesco, Al-Hijr">{{cite web |title=Al-Hijr Archaeological Site (Madâin Sâlih) |publisher=UNESCO |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1293 |accessdate=2014-04-07}}</ref>
[[Pork]] is ''[[haram]]'' ({{lang-ar|حَـرَام}}, forbidden) [[Religious restrictions on the consumption of pork#Prohibitions in Islamic law|to eat]], because its essence is considered impure, this is based on the verse of the Qur'an where it is described as being ''rijs'' ({{lang-ar|رِجـس}}, impure) ({{cite quran|6|145|style=ref}}).
Verses 50 and 51 of ''[[Surat al-Muddaththir]]'' in the Quran talk about ''ḥumur'' ({{lang|ar|حُـمُـر}}, '[[Syrian wild ass|asses]]' or '[[donkey]]s') fleeing from a ''[[qaswarah]]'' ({{lang|ar|قَـسـوَرَة}}, '[[Asiatic lion|lion]]', '[[beast of prey]]' or '[[hunter]]'), in its criticism of people who were averse to Muhammad's teachings, such as donating wealth to the less wealthy.<ref name="Cite quran|74|41|e=51|s=ns">{{cite quran|74|41|e=51|s=ns}}</ref><ref name="PalestinianBiologicalBulletin2006">{{cite web |url=http://www.geocities.com/jaffacity/Asiatic_Lion.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071112132359/http://www.geocities.com/jaffacity/Asiatic_Lion.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-11-12 |title=The Asiatic or Persian Lion (Panthera leo persica, Meyer 1826) in Palestine and the Arabian and Islamic Region |author=Khalaf-von Jaffa, N.A.B.A.T. |publisher=Wayback Machine |year=2006 |accessdate=2016-12-21}}</ref>
==''Sunnah''== {{Hadith}} ''Sunnah'' refers to the traditional biographies of Muhammad wherein examples of sayings attributed to him and his conduct have been recorded. [[Sunni Islam|Sunni]] and [[Shia Islam|Shi'a]] ''[[hadith]]'' (anecdotes about Muhammad) differ vastly, with Shi'a ''hadith'' generally containing more anthropomorphism and praise of animals.
Animals must not be mutilated while they are alive.<ref name="Forw">Susan J. Armstrong, Richard G. Botzler, ''The Animal Ethics Reader'', p.237, Routledge (UK) Press</ref>
Muhammad is also reported (by [[Abdullah ibn Umar|Ibn Omar]] and [['Abd Allah ibn 'Amr ibn al-'As|Abdallah bin Al-As]]) to have said: "there is no man who kills [even] a [[sparrow]] or anything smaller, without its deserving it, but God will question him about it [on the judgment day]" and "Whoever is kind to the creatures of God is kind to himself."<ref name="EoR&N"/><ref name="Hayawan"/>
Muhammad issued advice to kill animals that were ''[[Fasiq]]'' ({{lang-ar|فَـوَاسِـق}} "Harmful ones"), such as the rat and the [[scorpion]], within the holy area ''[[haram]]'' ({{lang-ar|حَـرَم}}, holy area) of [[Mecca]]. Killing other non-domesticated animals in this area, such as zebras and birds, is forbidden.<ref name=autogenerated1>Jürgen Wasim Frembgen (''Völkerkundemuseum''), "The Scorpion in Muslim Folklore", ''Asian Folklore Studies'', Volume 63 (2004), p. 95-123.</ref>
There is an account in the Qur'an's ''sura'' [[an-Naml]] of [[Solomon in Islam|Sulaymaan (Solomon)]] talking to ants.<ref>See {{cite quran|27|18|style=ref}}</ref> and birds.<ref>See {{cite quran|27|20|style=ref}}</ref>
Muslims are required to sharpen the blade when [[Dhabihah|slaughtering]] animals to ensure that no pain is felt.<ref name="Ves">P. Aarne Vesilind, Alastair S. Gunn, ''engineering, ethics, and the environment'', Cambridge University Press, p. 301.</ref> Muhammad is said: "For [charity showed to] each creature which has a wet liver [i.e. is alive], there is a reward."<ref name="EoR&N" /><ref name="z"/>
There is a ''hadith'' in [[Muwatta’ Imam Malik]] about [[Hajj|Muslim Pilgrims]] having to beware of the [[Arabian wolf|wolf]], besides other animals.<ref name="Cite Muwatta’ Imam Malik, B20, H794"/>
Ibn Mughaffal reported: "The Messenger of Allah (may peace be upon him) ordered the killing of rabid dogs, and then said: What about them, i. e. about other dogs? and then granted concession (to keep) the dog for hunting and the dog for (the security) of the herd, and said: When the dog licks the utensil, wash it seven times, and rub it with earth the eighth time." (From Muslim Book #002, Hadith #0551)
Ibn 'Umar reported "Allah's Messenger (may peace be upon him) giving the command for killing dogs..." (From Muslim Book #010, Hadith #3809)
Some Muslim commentators (e.g. Bassam Zawadi) suggest however that these killings were to be limited to "rabid dogs".<ref>[http://www.answering-christianity.com/bassam_zawadi/killing_of_dogs.htm/ Answering Christianity] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130929044433/http://www.answering-christianity.com/bassam_zawadi/killing_of_dogs.htm/ |date=September 29, 2013 }}</ref> primary source The majority of Muslim jurists consider dogs to be [[unclean animal|ritually unclean]], though jurists from the Sunni [[Maliki]] school disagree.<ref name="Fadl"/> However, outside their ritual uncleanness, Islamic ''[[Fatwā]]'', or rulings, enjoin that dogs be treated kindly or else be freed.<ref>[http://www.al-islam.org/organizations/aalimnetwork/msg00694.html ['Aalim Network QR] Dogs / Pets<!--Bot-generated title-->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411044136/http://www.al-islam.org/organizations/aalimnetwork/msg00694.html|date=April 11, 2008}}</ref> Muslims generally cast dogs in a negative light because of their ritual impurity. the story of the [[Seven Sleepers]] of [[Ephesus]] in the Qur'an (and also the role of the dog in early [[Christianity]]) is one of the striking exceptions.<ref>David Gordon White, ''Encyclopedia of Religion'', ''Dog'', p.2393</ref> though dogs are not recommended as pets, they are allowed to be kept, especially if used for work and protection, such as [[Guard dog|guarding]] the house or farm, or when used for [[Hunting dog|hunting]] purposes.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} Muhammad, the messenger of Allah (God) in Islam, is also reported as having reprimanded some men who were sitting idly on their [[camel]]s in a marketplace, saying "either ride them or leave them alone".<ref name="EoR&N" /><ref name="Hayawan" /> Apart from that, the camel has significance in Islam.<ref name="Mubarakpuri, The Sealed Nectar">{{cite book |last=Al Mubarakpuri |first=Safi ur Rahman |title=Ar-Raheeq Al-Makhtum (The Sealed Nectar): Biography of the Noble Prophet |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=r_80rJHIaOMC&pg=PA45 |accessdate=2014-10-06 |year= 2002 |publisher=Darussalam |isbn=9960-899-55-1 |pages=127–147}}</ref><ref name="Cite quran|15|80|e=84|s=ns">{{cite quran|15|80|e=84|s=ns}}</ref> Al-Qaswa' ({{lang-ar|الـقَـصـوَاء}}) was a female [[Arabian camel]] that belonged to Muhammad, and was dear to him.<ref name="Reeves"/> Muhammad rode on Qaswa during the ''[[Hegira]]'' ({{lang-ar|هِـجـرَة}}, 'Migration') from [[Mecca]] to [[Medina]], his [[Hajj]] in 629 [[Common Era|CE]], and the [[Conquest of Mecca]] in 630. The camel was also present during the [[Battle of Badr]] in 624. After the passing away of the Prophet, the Camel is reported to have starved itself to death, refusing to take food from anyone.<ref name="Mubarakpuri, The Sealed Nectar"/><ref name="Qaswa.net">{{cite web |title=‘Al-Qaswa’, what's behind the name? |publisher=Qaswa.net |url=http://www.qaswa.net/?page_id=303 |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref>
In the ''[[Nahj al-Balagha]]'', the Shi'a book of the sayings of [[Ali]], an entire sermon is dedicated to praising [[Peafowl|peacock]]s.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=zQjKHj0vA1IC&pg=PA333 Nahjul Balagha by ʻAlī ibn Abī Ṭālib, Muḥammad ibn al-Ḥusayn Sharīf al-Raḍī, Ali Ibn Abu Talib, Mohammad Askari Jafery, ʻAlam al-Hudá ʻAlī ibn al-Ḥusayn Sharīf al-Murtaḍá]</ref> [[Bee]]s are highly revered in Islam. The structural genius of a bee is thought as due to divine inspiration. Their product honey is also revered as medicine. Killing a bee is considered a great sin.<ref>Pessah Shinar ''Modern Islam in the Maghrib'' JSAI 2004 {{ISBN|978-9-657-25802-6}} page 390</ref><ref>Noel Scott ''Tourism in the Muslim World'' Emerald Group Publishing 2010 ISBN {{ISBN|978-1-849-50921-3}} page 51</ref>
In Shi'ite ''ahadith'', [[bat]]s are praised as a miracle of nature.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
The ''dhi’b'' ({{lang-ar|ذِئـب}}, [[wolf]]) may symbolize ferocity.<ref name="al-Tabari 1987 150">{{cite book|last=al-Tabari|first=Muhammad ibn Jarir (Translated by William Brinner)|title=The History of al-Tabari Vol. 2: Prophets and Patriarchs|year=1987|publisher=SUNY|page=150}}</ref><ref name="Cite Muwatta’ Imam Malik, B20, H794">[[Muwatta’ Imam Malik]], Book 20 ([[Hajj]]), Hadith 794</ref> As for the ''kalb'' ({{lang-ar|كَـلـب}}, [[dog]]), there are different views regarding it.<ref name="WattA">[[William Montgomery Watt]], ''Muhammad: Prophet and Statesman'', Oxford University Press, 1961, [http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/med/watt.html]</ref><ref name="Cite Muwatta’ Imam Malik, 2: 969">[[Malik ibn Anas]], ''al-Muwatta’'' (Egypt: al-Babi al-Halabi, n.d.), 2: 969.</ref> Some [[Islamic schools and branches|schools of Islamic law]] consider dogs as unclean (''[[najis]]''),<ref name=Waldau>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=5k6rAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA157|title=A Communion of Subjects: Animals in Religion, Science, and Ethics|publisher=Columbia University Press|page=157|author1=Paul Waldau|author2=Kimberley Patton}}</ref> while others, such as the [[Maliki]] school of Islamic jurisprudence distinguishes between wild dogs and pet dogs, only considering the saliva of the former to be impure.<ref name="Mattson2011">{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/ingrid-mattson/whats-up-with-muslims-and_b_1144819.html|title=What’s Up With Muslims and Dogs?|last=Mattson|first=Ingrid|date=13 December 2011|publisher=[[HuffPost]]|language=English|accessdate=2 June 2018}}</ref>
According to the Qur'an, the use of hunting dogs is permitted, which is a reason the Maliki school draws a distinction between feral and domesticated dogs―since Muslims can eat game that has been caught in a domesticated dog's mouth, the saliva of a domesticated dog cannot be impure.<ref name="Mattson2011"/> [[Khaled Abou El Fadl|Abou El Fadl]] "found it hard to believe that the same God who created such companionable creatures would have his prophet declare them 'unclean{{'"}}, stating that animosity towards dogs "reflected views far more consistent with pre-Islamic Arab customs and attitudes".<ref name=Banderker/> Furthermore, "he found that a hadith from one of the most trustworthy sources tells how the Prophet himself had prayed in the presence of his playfully cavorting dogs."<ref name=Banderker>{{cite web|url=http://www.islamicconcern.com/dogs.asp|title=Dogs in Islam|last=Banderker|first=Ayoub M.|date=15 April 2002|work=Newsweek|publisher=Islamic Concern|accessdate=26 May 2014}}</ref> Islamic scholar Ingrid Mattson teaches that for followers of other schools, "there are many other impurities present in our homes, mostly in the form of human waste, blood, and other bodily fluids" and that since it is common for these impurities to come in contact with a Muslim's clothes, they are simply washed or changed before prayer.<ref name="Mattson2011"/> The Qur'an (18:18) praises a group of dogs that guarded Muslims who were fleeing religious persecution.<ref name="Mattson2011"/> Mattson thus notes that "This tender description of the dog guarding the cave makes it clear that the animal is good company for believers."<ref name="Mattson2011"/>
The historian [[William Montgomery Watt]] states that Muhammad's kindness to animals was remarkable; he cites an instance of Muhammad while traveling with his army to Mecca in 630  CE, posting sentries to ensure that a female dog and her newborn puppies were not disturbed.<ref name="WattA"/> On the other hand, in a tradition found in the Sunni ''hadith'' book ''[[Muwatta Imam Malik|al-Muwatta’]]'', Muhammad is reported as saying that the company of dogs voids a portion of a Muslim's good deeds.<ref name="Cite Muwatta’ Imam Malik, 2: 969"/> However, in "two separate narrations by [[Abu Hurayrah]], the Prophet told his companions of the virtue of saving the life of a dog by giving it water and quenching its thirst. One story referred to a man who was blessed by Allah for giving water to a thirsty dog, the other was a prostitute who filled her shoe with water and gave it to a dog, who had its tongue rolling out from thirst. For this deed she was granted the ultimate reward, the eternal Paradise under which rivers flow, to live therein forever."<ref name="Islamweb, Animals">{{cite web|url=http://www.islamweb.net/emainpage/index.php?page=articles&id=76849|title=Islam teaches the love of animals|date=12 January 2004|publisher=IslamWeb|accessdate=26 May 2014}}</ref>
All of the [[Kutub al-Sittah]] record Hadiths prohibiting one from keeping dogs except for farming, herding and hunting, with those not keeping them for such purposes punished with deduction of ''qirat'' from their rewards each day.<ref>Narrated `Abdullah bin `Umar: Allah's Messenger said, "If someone keeps a dog neither for guarding livestock, nor for hunting, his good deeds will decrease (in reward) by two Qirats a day.' ([[Sahih al-Bukhari]], Book 72, [https://sunnah.com/bukhari/72/8 Hadith 8])<br>Ibn Umar (Allah be pleased with him) reported Allah's Messenger as saying: He who keeps a dog other than that meant for watching the herd or for hunting loses every day out of his deeds equal to two qirat. ([[Sahih al-Muslim]], Book 22, Hadith 62)<br>It was narrated from Salim, from his father, that the Messenger of Allah said: "Whoever keeps a dog. Except for a dog for hunting or herding livestock, two Qirats will be deducted from his reward each day." ([[Sunan an-Nisa’i]], Book 42, [https://sunnah.com/nasai/42/25 Hadith 25])<br>Narrated Abu Hurairah: The Prophet as saying: If anyone gets a dog, except a sheeping or hunting or a farm dog, a qirat of his reward will be deducted daily. ([[Sunan Abi Dawud]], Book 17, [https://sunnah.com/abudawud/17/1 Hadith 1])<br>It was narrated that Abu Hurairah said: “The Messenger of Allah said: ‘Whoever keeps a dog, one Qirat will be deducted from him (good) deeds every day, except a dog for farming or herding livestock.” ([[Sunan Ibn Majah]], Volume 4, Book 28, [https://sunnah.com/urn/1333260 Hadith 3204])<br>Narrated Ibn 'Umar: That the Messenger of Allah said: "Whoever keeps a dog" - or: "acquires a dog" - "neither of hunting nor to guard livestock, then two Qirat are deducted from his reward, daily." (Jami' al-Tirmidhi, Book 18, [https://sunnah.com/tirmidhi/18/29 Hadith 29])</ref> In a chapter on ''al-Musaqat'' ([[sharecropping]]), [[Muslim ibn al-Hajjaj]] records fifteen traditions on the spiritual loss incurred from domestication of dogs, with seven being on the authority of [[Abdullah ibn Umar|'Abd Allah ibn 'Umar]] and the other eight on [[Abu Hurairah]]'s authority. While five reports of Ibn Umar state two [[Carat (mass)|Carats]] (''Qiratan'') as a daily deduction for keeping dogs without a genuine purpose, the other two refer to deduction of only one Carat (''Qirat''). Only one report of Abu Hurairah mentions the deduction as two carats, while the other seven mentions it as one.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=jNiEbcmD520C|title=Authentication of Hadith: Redefining the Criteria|author=Israr Ahmed Khan|publisher=International Institute of Islamic Thought|page=xviii}}</ref> Three hadiths in ''"[[Dhabihah|Dhaba'iḥ]] and Sayd"'' of [[Sahih al-Bukhari]] are among some of the hadiths which include Ibn Umar's tradition regarding deduction of two qirats for the same.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=H-ebJHL4ShYC&pg=PA385|title=Ibn Ashur Treatise on Maqasid al-Shari'ah|publisher=The Other Press|page=385|author=Muhammad al- Tahir ibn Ashur}}</ref> According to a narration classified as authentic by [[Muslim ibn al-Hajjaj]], jet-black dogs with two spots on the eyes are a manifestation of evil in animal form;<ref>{{cite book|title=[[Sahih Muslim]], Book 10, Hadith 3813 (The Book of Transactions [Kitab Al-Buyu`])|quote=Abu Zubair heard Jabir b. 'Abdullah (Allah be pleased with him) saying: Allah's Messenger (may peace be upon him) ordered us to kill dogs, and we carried out this order so much so that we also kill the dog coming with a woman from the desert. Then Allah's Apostle (may peace be upon him) forbade their killing. He (the Holy Prophet further) said: It is your duty the jet-black (dog) having two spots (on the eyes), for it is a devil.}}</ref> however, according to [[Khaled Abou El Fadl]], the majority of scholars regard this to be "pre-Islamic Arab mythology" and "a tradition to be falsely attributed to the Prophet".<ref>{{cite web|title=Dogs in the Islamic Tradition and Nature|url=http://scholarofthehouse.org/dinistrandna.html|author=Khaled Abou El Fadl|year=2004|work=Encyclopedia of Religion and Nature|publisher=Scholar of the House|accessdate=26 May 2014|location=New York}}</ref><ref>Amira El-Zein ''Islam, Arabs, and Intelligent World of the Jinn'' Syracuse University Press 2009 {{ISBN|9780815650706}} page 124</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Foltz |first1=Richard |title=Animals in Islamic Traditions and Muslim Cultures |publisher=Oneworld Publications (November 1, 2005) |isbn=978-1851683987 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TFQQBwAAQBAJ}}</ref> In spite of El Fadl's views, the hadith today continue to publish that dogs are unclean and they annul prayers.<ref>Sahih Bukhari 1:9:493, See Also Sahih Bukhari 1:9:486, Sahih Muslim 4:1032, Sahih Muslim 4:1034, Sahih Muslim 4:1038, Sahih Muslim 4:1039</ref>
Domestic [[cat]]s have [[Islam and cats|a special place in Islamic culture]]. Muhammad is said to have loved his cat [[Muezza]] ({{lang-ar|مُـعِـزَّة}})<ref>[http://muttaqun.com/cats.html Cats]{{better source|date=December 2016}} {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070403055033/http://muttaqun.com/cats.html |date=April 3, 2007 }}</ref> to the extent that "he would do without his cloak rather than disturb one that was sleeping on it."<ref name="Reeves">Minou Reeves, ''Muhammad in Europe'', New York University (NYU) Press, p.52</ref>
[[Big cat]]s like the ''[[asad]]'' ({{lang|ar|أَسَـد}}, [[Arabian lion|lion]]), ''namir'' ({{lang|ar|نَـمِـر}}, [[Arabian leopard|leopard]]), and ''namur'' ({{lang|ar|نمر}}, [[Tiger]]), can symbolize ferocity, similar to the [[Arabian wolf|wolf]].<ref name="Cite Muwatta’ Imam Malik, B20, H794"/> Apart from ferocity, the [[lion]] has an important position in Islam and [[Arab culture]]. Men noted for their bravery, like Ali,<ref name="Britannica">{{cite encyclopedia|last=Nasr |first=Seyyed Hossein |authorlink=Seyyed Hossein Nasr |title=Ali |encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica Online |accessdate=2007-10-12 |publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc. |url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9005712/Ali |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071018014146/http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9005712/Ali |archivedate=October 18, 2007 <!--DASHBot-->|deadurl=no}}</ref> [[Hamzah ibn Abdul-Muttalib]]<ref name="Saad3">Muhammad ibn Saad. ''Kitab al-Tabaqat al-Kabair'' vol. 3. Translated by Bewley, A. (2013). ''The Companions of Badr''. London: Ta-Ha Publishers.</ref> and [[Omar Mukhtar]],<ref name="As-Salab2011">{{cite book |last= as-Salab |first=Ali Muhammad |authorlink= |title=Omar Al Mokhtar Lion of the Desert (The Biography of Shaikh Omar Al Mukhtar) |url= |accessdate= |year= 2011 |publisher= |location=Al-Firdous|isbn=978-1874263647|page=1|pages=}}</ref> were given titles like "Asad Allāh" ({{lang|ar|أَسَـد الله}}, "Lion of God") and "Asad aṣ-[[Sahara|Ṣaḥrā’]]" ({{lang|ar|أَسَـد الـصَّـحْـرَاء}}, "Lion of the Desert").
A spider is supposed to have saved [[Muhammad]] and [[Abu Bakr]] by spinning a web over the entrance of the cave in which they hid. Because of the web, the persecutor of them through the cave must be empty, otherwise, there would not have been a web. Therefore, Muslims consider killing spiders as a [[sin]].<ref>Gordon Newby ''A Concise Encyclopedia of Islam'' Oneworld Publications 2013 {{ISBN|978-1-780-74477-3}} "ankabut"</ref><ref>Thomas Riggs ''Worldmark Encyclopedia of Religious Practices: Countries A-L'' Thomson Gale 2006 {{ISBN|978-0-787-66613-2}} page 61</ref>
However, "jurists from the Sunni Maliki School disagree with the idea that dogs are unclean."<ref>{{cite web|title=Dogs and Islam: The Devil and the Seeing-Eye Dog |url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/canine-corner/201003/dogs-and-islam-the-devil-and-the-seeing-eye-dog |work=Psychology Today|last=Coren|first=Stanley|date=23 March 2010|publisher=Psychology Today|accessdate=26 May 2014}}</ref> Individual ''[[Fatwa|faṫāwā]]'' ({{lang-ar|فَـتَـاوَى}}, "rulings") have indicated that dogs be treated kindly or otherwise released<ref>[http://www.al-islam.org/organizations/aalimnetwork/msg00694.html ['Aalim Network QR] Dogs / Pets<!--Bot-generated title-->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411044136/http://www.al-islam.org/organizations/aalimnetwork/msg00694.html|date=April 11, 2008}}</ref> and earlier [[Islamic literature]] often portrayed dogs as symbols of highly esteemed virtues such as self-sacrifice and loyalty, which, in the hands of despotic and unjust rulers, become oppressive instruments.<ref name="Fadl">Khaled Abou El Fadl, "Dogs in the Islamic Tradition and Nature" in the [http://www.scholarofthehouse.org/dinistrandna.html ''Encyclopedia of Religion and Nature''], New York: Continuum International.</ref>
== Muslim cultures == Usually, in Muslim majority cultures, animals have names (one animal may be given several names), which are often interchangeable with names of people. Muslim names or titles like ''[[Asad (name)|asad]]'' and ''ghadanfar'' (Arabic for lion), ''shir'' and ''[[Aslan (disambiguation)|arslan]]'' ([[Persian language|Persian]] and [[Turkish language|Turkish]] for lion, respectively) are common in the [[Muslim world]]. Prominent Muslims with animal names include: Hamzah, Abd al-Rahman ibn Sakhr Al-[[Azd]]i (called "[[Abu Hurairah]]", the Father of the [[kitten]]), [[Abdul-Qadir Gilani]] (called ''al-baz al-ashhab'', the wise falcon) and [[Lal Shahbaz Qalander]] of [[Sehwan]] (called "red falcon").<ref name=Schimmel>[[Annemarie Schimmel]]. ''Islam and The Wonders of Creation: The Animal Kingdom''. [[Al-Furqan Islamic Heritage Foundation]], 2003. Pages 2-4</ref>
Islamic literature has many stories of animals. [[Arabic literature|Arabic]] and [[Persian literature]] boast many animal fables. The most famous, ''Kalilah wa-Dimnah'' or ''[[Panchatantra]]'', translated into Arabic by [[Abd-Allāh Ibn al-Muqaffaʿ]] in the 8th century, was also known in [[Europe]]. In the 12th century, Shihab al-Din al-Suhrawadi wrote many short stories of animals. At about the same time, in north-eastern [[Iran]], [[Attar Neyshapuri]] (Farid al-Din Attar) composed the epic poem ''Mantiq al-Tayr'' (meaning ''The Conference of the Birds'').<ref name=Schimmel />
In [[Malaysia]] in 2016, the Malaysian Islamic Development Department, a religious governing body, prohibited the use of the term ''[[hot dog]]'' to refer to the food of that name. It asked food outlets selling them to rename their products or risk refusal of halal certification. Per local media, Malaysian halal food guidelines prohibit naming halal products after non-halal products.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-37700495 BBC: "Hot dogs 'must be renamed' in Malaysia, says religious government body"] October 19, 2016</ref> Islamist organization [[Hamas]] which controls the [[Gaza Strip]], banned public dog walking in May 2017, stating it was to "protect our women and children". Hamas officials stated that the ban was in response to rise in dog walking on the streets which they stated was "against culture and traditions in Gaza".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/politics/hamas-gaza-strip-occupied-palestinian-territories-facebook-israel-dogs-dog-walking-a7746101.html|title=Hamas bans dog walking through the Gaza Strip to 'protect women and children'|publisher=The Independent}}</ref>
== Controversy ==
===Ritual slaughter=== {{main|Halal}} [[United Kingdom|UK]] [[animal welfare]] organizations have decried some ritual methods of slaughter practiced in Islam (''[[dhabihah]]'') and [[Judaism]] (''[[shechita]]'') as inhumane and causing "severe suffering".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk_news/story/0,3604,956385,00.html |work=The Guardian |location=London |title=Halal killing may be banned |first=Colin |last=Blackstock |date=May 15, 2003 |accessdate=May 5, 2010}}</ref><ref name="bbc">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/2977086.stm |work=BBC News |title=Halal and Kosher slaughter 'must end' |date=June 10, 2003 |accessdate=May 5, 2010}}</ref> According to Judy MacArthur Clark, Chairperson of the [[Farm Animal Welfare Council]], cattle require up to two minutes to [[Exsanguination|bleed to death]] when halal or kosher means of slaughter are used on cattle: "This is a major incision into the animal and to say that it doesn't suffer is quite ridiculous." In response, Majid Katme of the [[Muslim Council of Britain]] stated that "[i]t's a sudden and quick [[haemorrhage]]. A quick loss of blood pressure and the brain is instantaneously starved of blood and there is no time to start feeling any pain."<ref name="bbc"/>
In permitting ''dhabiha'', the [[Federal Constitutional Court of Germany|German Constitutional Court]] cited<ref>[http://www.bundesverfassungsgericht.de/entscheidungen/rs20020115_1bvr178399en.html Das Bundesverfassungsgericht<!-- Bot-generated title-->]</ref> the 1978 study led by Professor [[Wilhelm Schulze (professor of veterinary medicine)|Wilhelm Schulze]] at the [[University of Veterinary Medicine Hanover]] which concluded that "[t]he slaughter in the form of ritual cut is, if carried out properly, painless in sheep and calves according to the [[Electroencephalography|EEG]] recordings and the missing defensive actions."<ref name="schulze_halastudy">Schulze W, Schultze-Petzold H, Hazem AS, Gross R. "Experiments for the objectification of pain and consciousness during conventional (captive bolt-stunning) and religiously mandated (“ritual cutting”) slaughter procedures for sheep and calves", ''Deutsche Tierärztliche Wochenschrift'', 5;85(2) (February 1978), pp. 62-6. [http://www.mustaqim.co.uk/halalstudy.htm English translation]</ref> Muslims and [[Jew]]s have also argued that traditional British methods of slaughter have meant that "animals are sometimes rendered physically immobile, although with full consciousness and sensation. Applying a sharp knife in ''shechita'' and ''dhabh'', by contrast, ensures that no pain is felt: the wound inflicted is clean, and the loss of blood causes the animal to lose consciousness within seconds."<ref>{{cite book |first=Gerald |last=Parsons |title=The Growth of Religious Diversity: Britain from 1945 |location= |publisher=Routledge Press |isbn= |page=69 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MbSLmy-a23sC&pg=PA69 }}</ref> <!---- According to the Muslims, since that God has created humans have been created with a superior intellect than animals, we have the special responsibility to be fair, just and kind to all other livings. <ref name="animals">http://www.islamicedfoundation.com/askscholar/animal.htm</ref>{{Verify source|date=September 2008}} [[Muhammad]] once said that "Every injustice will be paid back on the Day of Judgment, even if one goat hits another with its horns it will be taken account of. Therefore, in our use of animals for our own survival, we must do justice." <ref name="animals">http://www.islamicedfoundation.com/askscholar/animal.htm</ref>{{Verify source|date=September 2008}} The court of Shari‘ah can imply rules on the humane treatment of animals based on the following quotations<ref name="quotes">http://www.islamonline.com/cgi-bin/news_service/fatwah_story.asp?service_id=539</ref>{{Verify source|date=September 2008}}:* As narrated in the [[hadith]], [[Ibn Umar|Abd-Allah ibn Umar]] stated that [[Muhammad]] said: “A woman was punished for a cat which she imprisoned until it died, and she entered Hell because of that. She did not feed it or give it water when she imprisoned it, and she did not leave it free to eat of the vermin of the earth.” (Narrated by [[Al-Bukhari]], {{Bukhari|2|2|36}}; Muslim, {{Muslim|2|2|42}}). In addition, [[Al-Nawawi]] said: the apparent meaning of the hadeeth is that she went to Hell only because of this sin."{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} ----->

"Dogs in the Islamic Tradition and Nature." A. {{short description|A private, non-profit center for global oceanography, ocean science education, and technology transfer.}} {{Infobox company | name = Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences | logo = Bigelow-logo.svg | logo_size = 300px | type = [[Non Profit]] | founded = {{Start date and age|1974|07}} | founders = {{plainlist| * Dr. Charles Yentsch * Dr. Clarice Yentsch }} | hq_location = 60 Bigelow Drive | hq_location_city = [[East Boothbay, Maine|East Boothbay]], [[Maine]] | hq_location_country = [[United States|U.S.]] | key_people = {{plainlist| * Dr. Deborah Bronk (President & CEO) }} | website = {{URL|www.bigelow.org}}
}}
'''Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences''', founded in 1974,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bigelow.org/about-bigelow-laboratory/history/|title=History|publisher=Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences|accessdate=January 24, 2013}}</ref> is a private, [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit]] center for global [[oceanography]], ocean science education, and technology transfer. The Laboratory’s research ranges from [[Microorganism|microbial]] oceanography to the large-scale [[Biogeochemistry|biogeochemical]] processes that drive ocean ecosystems and global environmental conditions, and is organized around the three core themes of Blue Biotechnology, Ocean Biogeochemistry and Climate Change, and Ocean Health. The Laboratory's 60,000 square-foot, shore-based campus is located in [[Boothbay Harbor, Maine|East Boothbay]], Maine, on the [[Damariscotta River]] estuary. In December 2012, the campus became the first [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] Platinum certified laboratory in Maine and one of seven in the New England area.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boothbayregister.com/article/bigelow-picks-prestigious-award/7202|title=Bigelow picks up prestigious award|author=Ben Bulkeley|date=December 18, 2012|work=Boothbay Register}}</ref> The Laboratory was recently rated one of the top 10 places to work in [[Maine]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boothbayregister.com/article/bigelow-maines-top-ten-best-places-work/4597|title=Bigelow in Maine's top ten best places to work|author=Lisa Kristoff|work=Booth Bay Register|date=October 17, 2012}}</ref>
The majority of the Laboratory's funding comes from federal and state grants and contracts,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pressherald.com/news/Bigelow-gets-federal-grants-totaling-more-than-1M-.html|title=Bigelow Lab gets federal grants of more than $1M|author=Associated Press|date=August 14, 2012|work=Portland Press Herald}}</ref> licenses and contracts with the private sector, and [[philanthropic]] support. Bigelow Laboratory supports the work of over 70 scientists and staff. The Laboratory also maintains a [[library]] open to the public both in East Boothbay and at McKown Point in West Boothbay Harbor, Maine, in collaboration with the Maine Department of Marine Resources.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bigelow.org/research/facilities/library/|title=Bigelow Laboratory and Maine Department of Marine Resources Library and Information Center|publisher=Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences|accessdate=January 24, 2013}}</ref>
The Laboratory’s primary research focus is on the microbial life and biogeochemical dynamics of the world’s ocean, advancing society’s understanding of the interactions between ocean ecosystems, global processes, and the environment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bigelow.org/about-bigelow-laboratory/information/ |title=Introduction |publisher=Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences |accessdate=January 24, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121113180430/http://www.bigelow.org/about-bigelow-laboratory/information/ |archivedate=November 13, 2012 |df= }}</ref> The Laboratory’s education programs include [[Undergraduate education|undergraduate]] training through a semester program offered in affiliation with [[Colby College]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.colby.edu/news_events/c/pr/072310/2235061/bigelow-laboratory-and-colby-college-form-strategic-partnership/|title=Bigelow Laboratory and Colby College form strategic partnership|date=July 23, 2010|publisher=Colby College press release}}</ref> and a [[National Science Foundation]]-funded summer Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bigelow.org/education/reu/|title=Research Experience for Undergraduates Gulf of Maine and the World Ocean|publisher=Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences|accessdate=January 24, 2013}}</ref> The Laboratory is also the home to several service facilities, including the Provasoli-Guillard National Center for Marine Algae and Microbiota (NCMA), the Single Cell Genomics Center (SCGC) <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://scgc.bigelow.org/|title=Single Cell Genomics Center :: Home|website=scgc.bigelow.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-25}}</ref>, and the J.J. MacIsaac Facility for Aquatic Cytometry.
==History== The Laboratory was established by Drs. Charles and Clarice Yentsch<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2012/09/22/news/midcoast/renowned-maine-based-scientist-known-as-beloved-maverick-dies-at-age-85/|title=Renowned Maine-based scientist known as ‘beloved maverick’ dies at age 85|author=Christopher Cousins|date=September 22, 2012|work=BDN Maine Midcoast}}</ref> in 1974 as a private, non-profit research institution named for the [[Oceanography|oceanographer]] [[Henry Bryant Bigelow]], founding Director of the [[Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution]]. Dr. Bigelow’s extensive investigations in the early part of the twentieth century are recognized as the foundation of modern oceanography.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://harvardmagazine.com/1999/01/vita.html|title=Henry Bryant Bigelow|author=David Dobbs|work=Harvard Magazine|date=January 1999}}</ref> His multi-year expeditions in the [[Gulf of Maine]], where he collected water samples and data on [[phytoplankton]], fish populations, and [[hydrography]], established a new [[paradigm]] of intensive, [[Ecology|ecologically]]-based oceanographic research in the United States and made this region one of the most thoroughly studied bodies of water, for its size, in the world.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://fisherybulletin.noaa.gov/53-1/intro.pdf|title=Fishes of the Gulf of Maine|author=Henry B. Bigelow and William C. Schroeder|work=Fishery Bulletin of the Fish and Wildlife Service|date=1953|publisher=Museum of Comparative Zoology, Harvard University, and Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution|accessdate=January 28, 2013}}</ref>
Since its founding, the Laboratory has attracted over $100 million in federal grants for research projects, winning competitive, peer reviewed awards from all of the principal federal research granting agencies. The Laboratory’s total operating revenue (including philanthropy) has grown by 68% over the past six years to $7.9 million in the fiscal year ending June 30, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bigelow.org/news/annual-report-2011/ |title=Annual Report 2011 |publisher=Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences |accessdate=January 28, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130221150624/http://www.bigelow.org/news/annual-report-2011/ |archivedate=February 21, 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref name="mainebiz">{{cite news|url=http://www.mainebiz.biz/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20121001%2FCURRENTEDITION%2F309279999%2F0%2FNEWS0101|title=New Bigelow lab opens more ocean science possibilities|date=October 1, 2012|author=Lori Valigra|work=MainBiz}}</ref> Federal research grants have supported most of the Laboratory’s research operations and administrative needs in the past; education and outreach programs have relied on other sources of support, primarily contributions from individuals and private philanthropic foundations.
From 2008 until his death in December 2016, the Laboratory’s [[executive director]] was [[Graham Shimmield]], Ph.D., [[Royal Society of Edinburgh|FRSE]], a marine [[Geochemistry|geochemist]] and former director of the Scottish Association of Marine Sciences.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mainebiz.biz/article/20111017/CURRENTEDITION/310179981|title=Sea changer, Graham Shimmield, executive director, Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences, West Boothbay Harbor|date=October 17, 2011|work=MainBiz}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bigelow.org/news/articles/2016-12-27.html|title=Executive Director Graham Shimmield Passes Away|date=December 27, 2016}}</ref> Interim Executive Director is Benjamin Twining, Ph.D..
==Mission== Bigelow Laboratory’s [[Mission statement|mission]] is to undertake and sustain excellence in fundamental research into the [[ecosystem]]s of the world’s ocean and thereby comprehend their relevance to a changing world; to promote the education and enlightenment of ocean science to society at all ages; and to directly contribute to the sustainability of research, enterprise, and knowledge exchange, both locally and nationally. Bigelow Laboratory seeks to understand key processes driving ocean ecosystems, their evolution, and their fundamental relationship to life on Earth through interrelated programs in research, education, and technology transfer. Its focus ranges from microbial oceanography to the large-scale dynamics of the global ocean.
==Organization== The Laboratory’s Ocean Science and Education Campus facilities and infrastructure in East Boothbay, Maine are organized into three “Centers of Discovery”.<ref name="mainebiz" />
'''Norton Center for Blue Biotechnology''' (NCBB). Research in the NCBB applies [[molecular biology]] and [[microbial ecology]] to the [[virus]]es, [[bacteria]], [[archaea]], and [[algae]] living in diverse environments throughout the world’s oceans in order to understand their [[evolution]], [[Genetics|genetic]] and chemical make-up, and their culture and industrial application. NCBB scientists work with the reservoir of microbial organisms in the natural environment and those preserved in cultures. The NCBB houses the world’s first microbial single cell genomics facility (SCGC),<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.biotechniques.com/BiotechniquesJournal/2012/May/Single-cell-Genomics-Defining-Microbiologys-Dark-Matter/biotechniques-330550.html?service=print|title=Single-cell Genomics: Defining Microbiology's Dark Matter|author=Jeffrey M. Perkel, Ph.D|work=BioTechniques|page=301–303|volume=52|number=5|date=May 5, 2012}}</ref> the Provasoli-Guillard National Center for Marine Algae and Microbiota (NCMA), containing one of the world’s first combined collections of marine algae, bacteria, archaea, and viruses; a flow [[cytometry]] laboratory; a [[bioreactor]] facility; and a laboratory focused on the oceanic deep biosphere.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://maineinsights.com/perma/marine-scientist-explores-hidden-terrain |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130216104936/http://maineinsights.com/perma/marine-scientist-explores-hidden-terrain |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 16, 2013 |title=Marine scientist explores hidden terrain |author=Emily du Houx |work=Maine Insights |date=October 16, 2012 }}</ref>
'''Center for Ocean Biogeochemistry and Climate Change''' (COBCC). The research conducted at the COBCC addresses questions of ocean [[biogeochemistry]] and [[climate change]] at many scales, from local to global, and from individual cells to entire ocean basins. By bringing together the research activities in ocean observing, air-sea interactions, ocean biogeochemistry, cellular biogeochemistry, and land-sea interactions into a single, integrated space, the COBCC catalyzes the collaboration needed to provide scientific information on the role of microscopic marine communities in global ocean processes and climate change.
'''Center for Ocean Health''' (COH). Collectively, Bigelow Laboratory’s research brings a [[systems biology]] perspective to oceanographic research. Current developments in microbial and genomic research offer the opportunity to develop fundamental new research methods in ocean systems that go beyond traditional field-to-laboratory approaches. Research in the COH is focused on advancing the knowledge needed for future management and [[stewardship]] of marine ecosystems.
==Education programs== The Laboratory’s education activities include high school, undergraduate, and professional training programs; [[postdoctoral research|postdoctoral]] training and mentoring; public events and programs based on the international [[Café Scientifique]] model; and online resources for teachers and students.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bigelow.org/Education/|title=Education|publisher=Bigelow Laboratory|accessdate=January 28, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130222050337/http://www.bigelow.org/education/|archivedate=February 22, 2013|df=}}</ref>
At the high school level, Bigelow Laboratory offers the annual Keller BLOOM (Bigelow Laboratory Orders Of Magnitude) program for Maine high school juniors, and the BLOOM Educators' program for Maine teachers to bring ocean science into their classrooms. The week-long BLOOM programs offer participants the opportunity work alongside professional researchers, exploring the biological, chemical and geological characteristics of the local marine environment through field and laboratory work.
As part of its affiliation with Colby College in Waterville, Maine, the Laboratory offers a full semester of courses in residence at the Bigelow campus. Students live in East Boothbay, take classes from Bigelow scientists, learn how to conduct field research through a field course on the [[Damariscotta River|Damariscotta]] River, and conduct independent research with a scientist. mentor<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boothbayregister.com/article/microscopic-beginnings/5828|title=Microscopic beginnings|work=Boothbay Register|date=November 16, 2012|author=Ben Bulkeley}}</ref> In addition, Bigelow senior scientists teach in Waterville during in the college’s “January Program,” a five-week period of intensive single course offerings between the fall and spring academic terms.
The Laboratory annually offers a ten-week summer training program as a national site of the [[National Science Foundation|NSF]]-funded Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program.
==Technology transfer== The Laboratory has established an Office of Corporate Alliances and Technology Transfer,<ref name="mainebiz" /> which works with the science staff to build portfolios of proprietary and protected [[intellectual property]], and establish relationships with [[private sector]] partners who can help the Laboratory [[Commerce|commercialize]] marketable technologies.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2013/01/11/business/bigelow-labs-partners-with-mississippi-school-to-develop-commercial-cosmetics-and-pharmaceutical-products/|title=Bigelow Labs partners with Mississippi school to develop commercial cosmetics and pharmaceutical products|work=BDN Maine|author=Seth Koenig|date=January 11, 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

[[File:Llandreinio Bridge and Rodney's Pillar, 1794.jpg|thumb|Llandrinio Bridge and Rodney's Pillar, 1794]] [[File:Breidden Hill surrounded in mist - geograph.org.uk - 51511.jpg|thumb|right|Breidden Hill]] [[File:Snow at Rodney's Pillar (365m) - geograph.org.uk - 1718310.jpg|thumb|right|Rodney's Pillar on Breidden Hill]] '''Breidden Hill''' is an [[extinct volcano|extinct]] volcanic hill in [[Powys]], Wales, near the town of [[Welshpool]]. It is immediately surrounded by the villages of [[Trewern]], [[Criggion]], [[Crew Green]] and [[Llandrinio]]. The peak of the hill reaches to {{convert|367|m|ft}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ybkHAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA158&lpg=PA158&dq=breidden+hill+height+ft&source=web&ots=tLQ1LgIFg0&sig=jAdH43AwVSoqU2deY4oXZ1qJgRI|title=Handbook for travellers in North Wales|work=google.com|accessdate=16 February 2015}}</ref> Footpaths which lead up to the summit provide excellent 360 degree views over Powys and over the [[England–Wales border|border]] with England to the [[Shropshire#Geography|Shropshire Plain]].
Breidden Hill is one of five peaks with neighbouring '''Moel y Golfa''', which is the highest at {{convert|403|m|ft}}, which is a "[[Marilyn (hill)|Marilyn]]", with a prominence of {{convert|261|m|ft}}. The three others are Cefn y Castell (also known as Middletown Hill), Kempsters Hill and Bausley Hill (over {{convert|800|ft|m}} high) with its [[British Iron Age|Iron Age]] galleried fortification. The five hills are sometimes collectively known as the Breidden Hills, and form a northern extension of the [[Long Mountain (Powys)|Long Mountain]].
There are remains of a [[British Iron Age]] [[hillfort]] en route which may have been the site of the last stand of [[Caractacus]]. Rodney's Pillar at the top was built by the gentlemen of [[Montgomeryshire]] who supplied [[oak]] [[wood]] from the area and shipped it down the [[River Severn]] (which runs nearby at [[Bausley with Criggion]]) to [[Bristol]] where [[George Brydges Rodney, 1st Baron Rodney|Admiral Rodney's]] [[Man-of-war|naval fleet]] was built. Rodney's Pillar is increasingly being used as a navigational aid by helicopter pilots in this area, due to its visibility from large areas of Wales.
Beginning around 1789, for many years members of the Breidden Society, founded by John Dovaston (1740–1808), met near Rodney's Pillar for an annual festival of food, drink, poetry, and song; records of their meetings for 1809–15 are preserved at the [[Houghton Library]] of [[Harvard University]] (MS Eng 1168).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hollis.harvard.edu/primo_library/libweb/action/dlDisplay.do?vid=HVD&docId=HVD_ALEPH009380801&fn=permalink|title=Antiquities, biography, poetry, etc. : manuscript, 1801–1940.|work=harvard.edu|accessdate=16 February 2015}}</ref>
There is a large [[quarry]] on the western and northern sides of Breidden Hill. The rock is a thick gabbroic-dolerite [[laccolith]], which is a source of roadstone.<ref>Rawson, P. F. and Brenchley, P. J. (2006) ''The Geology of England and Wales'' Geological Society of London {{ISBN|978-1-86239-200-7}} p.63 in [https://books.google.com/books?id=-6gqvAbdS-MC&pg=PA63&lpg=PA63&dq=Moel+y+Golfa&source=bl&ots=cwzWRv_oX5&sig=sPTKKdAFDaMyX1Ac6mA4NCcG3Bc&hl=en&ei=UWVcSvGpH5-UjAf07KjPDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2 Google Books]</ref>
On 27 June 2018, [[2018 United Kingdom wildfires|a wildfire]] broke out on Breidden Hill, destroying an area of grassland close to Rodney's Pillar.

ChEMBL = 502216 | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/C2ClF5/c3-1(4,5)2(6,7)8 | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = RFCAUADVODFSLZ-UHFFFAOYSA-N | CASNo = 76-15-3 | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|correct|CAS}} | EINECS = 200-938-2 | PubChem = 6430 | SMILES = FC(F)(F)C(Cl)(F)F | InChI = 1/C2ClF5/c3-1(4,5)2(6,7)8 | RTECS = KH7877500 | UNNumber = 1020 | MeSHName = | ChEBI_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEBI = | KEGG_Ref = {{keggcite|correct|kegg}} | KEGG = }} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | Formula = C<sub>2</sub>ClF<sub>5</sub> | MolarMass =154.466 g/mol | Appearance = Colorless gas | Odor = Ethereal | Density = | MeltingPtC = -99 | MeltingPt_notes = | BoilingPtC = -39.1 | BoilingPt_notes = | Solubility = 59 mg/L | SolubleOther = | Solvent = | pKa = | pKb = | VaporPressure = 7.9 atm (21°C)<ref name=PGCH/> }} |Section7={{Chembox Hazards | EUClass = | MainHazards = In high concentrations may cause asphyxiation.<ref>[http://encyclopedia.airliquide.com/sds/en/030_AL_EN.pdf http://encyclopedia.airliquide.com/sds/en/030_AL_EN.pdf]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> | NFPA-H = | NFPA-F = | NFPA-R = | NFPA-S = | GHSSignalWord = Warning | GHSPictograms = {{GHS01}}{{GHS07}} | HPhrases = {{H-phrases|280|420}} | PPhrases = {{P-phrases|410+403|502}} | RSPhrases = | FlashPtC = 70.4 | AutoignitionPtC = | ExploLimits = | PEL = none<ref name=PGCH>{{PGCH|0131}}</ref> | REL = TWA 1000 ppm (6320 mg/m<sup>3</sup>)<ref name=PGCH/> | IDLH = N.D.<ref name=PGCH/> }} }} '''Chloropentafluoroethane''' is a [[chlorofluorocarbon]] once used as a [[refrigerant]]. Its production and consumption has been banned since 1 January 1996 under the [[Montreal Protocol]] because of its ozone-depleting potential.<ref>[http://www.scorecard.org/chemical-groups/one-list.tcl?short_list_name=ods Ozone Depleting Substances List (Montreal Protocol)]</ref>

{{Infobox protected area | name = Curt Gowdy State Park | iucn_category = III | iucn_ref = {{cite web|title=Curt Gowdy State Park|url=https://www.protectedplanet.net/curt-gowdy-state-park|website=Protected Planet|publisher=IUCN|accessdate=1 May 2018}} | photo = Curt Gowdy State Park 1.jpg | photo_caption = circa 2008 | map = USA#Wyoming | map_image = | map_size = 240 | map_caption = | relief = 1 | location = [[Laramie County, Wyoming|Laramie]], [[Albany County, Wyoming|Albany]], Wyoming, United States | nearest_city = | nearest_town = | coordinates = {{coord|41|10|25|N|105|13|36|W|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = | length = | length_mi = | length_km = | width = | width_mi = | width_km = | area_acre = 3395 | area_ref = | elevation = {{convert|7598|ft|m|abbr=on}} | elevation_avg = | elevation_min = | elevation_max = | dimensions = | designation = | authorized = | created = | designated = | established = 1971
(renamed for Gowdy in 1972) | named_for = [[Curt Gowdy]], sportscaster | visitation_num = 150,653 | visitation_year = 2015 | visitation_ref = | governing_body = [[Wyoming Division of State Parks and Historic Sites]] | administrator = | operator = | owner = | website = [http://wyoparks.state.wy.us/index.php/places-to-go/curt-gowdy Curt Gowdy State Park] | embedded = }} '''Curt Gowdy State Park''' is a public recreation area in the [[Western United States|western]] [[United States]], located in [[Wyoming]] on [[Wyoming Highway 210|state highway 210]]. It is halfway between [[Cheyenne, Wyoming|Cheyenne]] and [[Laramie, Wyoming|Laramie]], about {{convert|25|mi|round=5}} from each, in [[Albany County, Wyoming|Albany]] and [[Laramie County, Wyoming|Laramie]] counties. The [[state park]] covers {{convert|3395|acre|sqmi km2|1}} and is known for its extensive trail system, fishing reservoirs, and [[Hynds Lodge]], which is listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. The park is managed by the [[Wyoming Division of State Parks and Historic Sites]]. ==History== The park was established {{Years or months ago|1971}} in 1971 through a lease agreement with the City of Cheyenne and the [[Boy Scouts of America|Boy Scouts]]. It was originally called Granite State Park and covered {{convert|2473|acre|sqmi km2|1}}. The following year, it was renamed in honor of national [[sportscaster]] and outdoorsman [[Curt Gowdy]] (1919–2006), a Wyoming native. Born in [[Green River, Wyoming|Green River]], he was raised in Cheyenne and was a two-sport varsity athlete ([[Wyoming Cowboys basketball|basketball]], tennis) at the [[University of Wyoming|university]] in Laramie. In 2006, the park saw initiation of an [[International Mountain Bicycling Association]] (IMBA) trail improvement project. The trail system earned the IMBA's "Epic" designation in 2009. In 2009, Wyoming began a program to build additional hiking trails in several Wyoming state parks. Curt Gowdy State Park served as the pilot project for the program, with 32 miles of additional trails. The state required that the newly built trails do not fundamentally alter the landscape of the park. Funding for the trails came from federal and state funds and private donations. Trail improvements resulted in a substantial increase in visitorship with number of annual visitors to the park increasing from 56,000 in 2006 to 120,000 in 2013. To accommodate the park's newfound popularity, a new state-of-the-art, green-certified, visitor center was opened in 2014. ==Geography== Park terrain consists of rolling hills and sharp granite outcroppings in the foothills of the [[Laramie Mountains]]. Elevation ranges from {{convert|6450|ft}} to over {{convert|7500|ft|-1}}. Wildlife that can be found include: [[Sockeye salmon|kokanee salmon]], [[perch]], [[brown trout|brown]], [[rainbow trout|rainbow]] and [[lake trout]], [[white-tailed deer]], and [[mule deer]]. The park is divided into seven sections centering around three reservoirs: Granite Springs, the largest, Crystal, the smallest, and the isolated North Crow, located northwest of the main park. ==Activities and amenities== The park offers over {{convert|35|mi|round=5}} of trails for biking, hiking, and horseback riding. Other activities include boating, canoeing, water skiing, fishing, camping, rockhounding, and archery. ==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |url=http://wyoparks.state.wy.us/index.php/places-to-go/curt-gowdy |title=Curt Gowdy State Park |work=Wyoming State Parks, Historic Sites & Trails |publisher=State of Wyoming |accessdate=August 22, 2017}} {{cite web |url=http://wyoparks.state.wy.us/pdf/Planning/CurtGowdyVisitorCenterInterpretivePlan2013.pdf |title=Curt Gowdy State Park Visitor Center Interpretive Plan |author=Dennis Henry |publisher=Wyoming Department of State Parks and Cultural Resources |page=2 |date=April 12, 2014 |accessdate=June 23, 2016}} {{cite web |url=http://wyoparks.state.wy.us/pdf/Planning/Soar2021.pdf |title=Table 1. Facilities managed by Wyoming State Parks, Historic Sites and Trails |work=SOAR 2021 |publisher=Wyoming Department of State Parks and Cultural Resources |page=12 |accessdate=August 22, 2017}} {{cite web |url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwyoparks.state.wy.us%2Findex.php%2Ffiles%2F580%2FVisitation+Statistics+and+Use+Surveys%2F519%2F2015+Visitor+Use+Report+-+Final.pdf%3Ftoken%3Da620b085dae09268e00994228295fd35%26preview%3D1&embedded=true |title=Visitor Use Program |publisher=Wyoming State Parks, Historic Sites & Trails |date=2015 |page=5 |accessdate=August 22, 2017}} {{cite web |url=http://wyoparks.state.wy.us/pdf/Maps/curt%20gowdy%20trails%20map%202016%20-%2024x25.pdf |title=Curt Gowdy State Park Trails |publisher=Wyoming Department of State Parks and Cultural Resources |date=2016 |accessdate=June 23, 2016}} {{cite web |url=http://wyomingplaces.pbworks.com/w/page/81377075/Curt%20Gowdy%20State%20Park |title=Curt Gowdy State Park |work=Wyoming Places |publisher=Wyoming State Library |accessdate=December 1, 2015}} {{cite web|url=http://www.wyomingtourism.org/overview/Curt-Gowdy-State-Park/2843|title=Curt Gowdy State Park|publisher=Wyoming Tourism|accessdate=January 7, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120417054814/http://www.wyomingtourism.org/overview/Curt-Gowdy-State-Park/2843|archivedate=April 17, 2012|df=}} {{cite news |url=http://gazette.com/epic-thrills-in-store-for-mountain-bikers-at-wyomings-curt-gowdy-state-park/article/1533906/ |title=Thrills in store for mountain bikers at Wyoming's Curt Gowdy State Park |first=Lance |last=Benzel |newspaper=Colorado Springs Gazette |date=July 17, 2014 |accessdate=June 23, 2016}} {{cite web|url=http://www.imba.com/epics/curt-gowdy-state-park|work=Epics|title=Curt Gowdy State Park|publisher=International Mountain Biking Association|accessdate=January 7, 2012}} {{cite news |url=http://trib.com/news/state-and-regional/article_5f9101ac-f97d-53d6-b2bb-9ced55a44699.html |title=Wyo looks to expand trails at state parks |date=March 17, 2009 |last=Korn |first=Marjorie |newspaper=Casper Star-Tribune |accessdate=January 6, 2012}} {{cite web |url=http://www.publiclands.org/explore/site.php?id=1572 |title=Curt Gowdy State Park |publisher=Public Lands Information Center |accessdate=January 7, 2012}} }} ==External links== {{commons
